awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Multi-View Latent Class Discovery and Prediction with a Streamlined Analytics Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
Discovering latent subgroups in a sample is an important problem in many scientific disciplines. Social scientists identify subgroups within a population based on behavioral patterns to examine differential effects of social status. Engineers recognize malfunctions of a manufacturing system based on performance measures to detect design defects. Physicians define subtypes of a disorder on the basis of clinical symptoms to identify associated genetic risk factors. This kind of problem involves two sets of variables: a set of descriptors describing the issue (e.g., behavioral patterns, or symptoms) and a set of moderators or predictors (e.g., social status, or genetic factors). The ability to accurately predict the latent classes (e.g., disease subtypes) from predictors (e.g., genetic risk) in the absence of observed descriptors (e.g., before symptoms are developed) will advance many of these disciplines. This project aims to develop an effective and efficient platform of machine learning algorithms to solve this problem. The team will effectively integrate research and teaching to engage students into the proposed study. Validated methods and software will be broadly disseminated through the project web repository and scientific presentations.

This project addresses the latent class discovery and prediction problem by deriving novel and efficient approaches, including multi-view co-clustering, multi-view subspace clustering, multi-objective optimization of co-training, and multi-modal deep learning methods. Parallel and distributed algorithms will be developed to implement and scale up these methods. A streamlined analytics platform will be constructed to maximize the utility of the proposed approaches in real-world applications. The proposed solutions will be evaluated in the analysis of large-scale sensory and behavioral data. By collaborating with domain experts, the project will (1) identify risk factors for problematic human behaviors such as binge drinking; and (2) locate the sensory features most discriminative of gait abnormalities due to neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease or stroke.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop effective approaches to discover latent classes or structures of data and create predictive models based on the data to predict the classes. Scalable/parallel algorithms and a streamlined analytic platform were also derived to maximize the utility of the proposed approaches in real-life applications. The developed algorithms were tested on a variety of application domains to detect modes from sensor data or patterns from behavioral variables. The project was successful, and new algorithms and application results were reported in six journal articles and ten conference proceedings. The following directions were the research focus of this project.

(1)           Multi-modal and integrative data analytics. Five different methods were developed in this direction. Two multi-view modeling methods were designed to, respectively, impute missing data in one view based on data from another view, and merge graph connectivity information from different graphs via the attention mechanism to improve sample categorization. Multi-modal methods were also developed to integrate different biosensing data in a specific application to recognize gait patterns of human subjects where the first method was focused on algorithm scalability, the second method was capable of classifying abnormal gaits from healthy gaits, and the third method addressed the nature of sequence data.

(2)           Graph and graph structure learning. In many areas, data samples are represented by graphs which were the data structure in our application domains, such as communication networks or manufactural sensor networks. A method was derived to improve dynamic graph learning through fault tolerant sparsification when a communication network is represented as a graph. Another method aimed to learn discrete graph structure to forecast multiple time series collected from a sensor network.

(3)           Real-time data analytics infrastructure. A real-time data analytic platform called RT-DAP was proposed for the algorithms of this project to run on-demand and was tested in large-scale industrial process monitoring and control. Another approach for online reconfiguration of regularity-based resource partitions was developed to improve cyber-physical systems.

(4)           Parallel and federated algorithms. Three scalable or federated learning algorithms were designed and investigated. A privacy-preserving optimization algorithm was designed to optimize the nonconvex and nonsmooth optimization problem formulated in sparse modeling. Sparse modeling techniques are important in this project because they help identify important features in defining the latent classes and to predict the classes. A federated learning algorithm was developed for sparse learning so the learning process can benefit from a federation of many edge computing devices that all participate in the learning. Further, a federated learning algorithm was developed for reinforcement learning and tested effective on an indoor localization problem.

Additionally, a review paper was published on an important application "neurorehabilitation" where we reviewed and discussed the advances in automation technologies for neurorehabilitation and future challenges. A multi-task learning method was examined to improve the classification of neurological gait disorders.

This project partially supported the research of three postdoc researchers and seven PhD students, including three students' PhD dissertation research. Among these researchers, a postdoc fellow successfully identified a tenure-track faculty position at a four-year college or university of the US and two other postdoc fellows pursued other academic positions (e.g., research professorship). Three PhD students have graduated, one working as data scientist in an AI company and two working with network device companies. The two principal investigators factored the project products and findings into the teaching of their respective courses.

 


Last Modified: 11/03/2022
Modified by: Jinbo Bi
